causes: Carthage's recovery and economic resurgence after the Second Punic War (218–201 BCE), despite Roman restrictions on their military power.
The continued Roman suspicion and hostility towards Carthage due to its wealth and proximity to Roman-controlled territories in Spain and North Africa.
Roman desire to eliminate Carthage as a potential rival power in the Mediterranean.
events_leading_up_to_war: Following the defeat of Carthage in the Second Punic War, Rome imposed heavy restrictions on Carthage, including limiting its army and forbidding military actions without Roman consent.
Despite these restrictions, Carthage's economy grew, and the city rebuilt its fortifications, leading to Roman accusations of violating peace terms.
A crisis in the region, particularly with Rome's allies in the region, led to growing Roman demands for the complete destruction of Carthage.

result.territorial_changes: Carthage was razed to the ground, and its territory became part of the Roman Empire. The city was rebuilt later by the Romans as a new Roman colony.

Rome.siege_equipment: Advanced siege technology, including ballistae and siege towers

Carthage.siege_defenses: High city walls, defensive structures, and determined defenders

Carthage.wounded: Majority of defenders killed or enslaved

major_battles.name: Siege of Carthage
major_battles.description: The Roman siege of Carthage was marked by intense fighting, including repeated assaults on the city's walls and a devastating naval blockade. It ended with the complete destruction of Carthage.
major_battles.outcome: Roman victory; Carthage was utterly destroyed and its population either killed or enslaved.

texts.name: Cicero’s Letters and History
texts.details: Cicero and other Roman historians recount the brutality of the siege and the destruction of Carthage, with some praising Scipio Aemilianus for his leadership.

archaeological_evidence.description: The remains of Carthage, including the Carthaginian city walls and Roman-built structures, still exist in modern Tunisia as part of the archaeological site.
Coins from the Carthaginian era have been uncovered, depicting Carthage’s military leaders and the symbolism of their empire, before the destruction.

historical_texts.name: Polybius' 'History of Rome'
historical_texts.details: Polybius describes the Roman military strategy in the Third Punic War and the critical role of the siege in the conflict's outcome.

historical_texts.name: Appian of Alexandria’s 'History of Rome'
historical_texts.details: Appian recounts the final years of Carthage and the Senate's decision to completely destroy the city, emphasizing Roman resolve.

political: Carthage’s complete destruction eliminated the last major threat to Roman dominance in the Western Mediterranean.
Rome gained control of North Africa, securing a vital grain-producing region.
long_term_effects: Rome’s control over North Africa helped its military and economic expansion across the Mediterranean.
The destruction of Carthage sent a clear message to other rival powers in the Mediterranean about Rome’s power and resolve.

military: The destruction of Carthage demonstrated Rome’s military superiority and their resolve in eliminating all threats to their dominance.
The siege tactics used by Rome were key to their victory, showcasing advanced siege warfare techniques.
political: The war marked the final end of Carthaginian power and solidified Roman supremacy in the Mediterranean.
The Roman Senate’s decision to annihilate Carthage also highlighted the extreme measures taken by the Republic to ensure peace and control.
cultural: The complete destruction of Carthage was symbolic of Rome’s unwillingness to tolerate any rival, shaping the identity of Rome as an unchallenged superpower.
The war also contributed to the legendary status of Scipio Aemilianus and the harshness of Roman governance in the eyes of their enemies.
